summary.seg: This small, beautifully decorated manuscript contains the Greek Hours of the Virgin (use of Rome), with the seven Penitential Psalms. This Greek translation was published by Aldus Manutius in 1497; the translation of the Latin text has been attributed to a member of Manutius' circle in Venice, Justin Dekadyos (Decaduo, Δεκαδύος) (see G.R. Parpulov, An Aldine Book of Hours (91.1273), in: A Catalogue of Greek Manuscripts at the Walters Art Museum and Essays in Honor of Gary Vikan (= The Journal of the Walters Art Museum 62 [2004]), pp. 233-235, with cited bibliogrphy). The manuscript was copied by a single hand, probably between the last years of the 15th and the first quarter of the 16th century, and is decorated in a western style which recalls examples from the region of France at the end of the 15th century (see e.g. Cambridge, University Library, Add. 7314, Add. 4112, Mm.6.14 with a comparable decoration, produced in France at the end of the 15th century, see for details P. Binski, P. Zutshi, Western Illuminated Manuscripts. A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library, Cambridge 2011).
It is not uncommon to find Greek translations of Latin devotional texts among the collections of humanist scholars (see Parpulov 2004).

msItem.title: Greek translation of the Greek Hours of the Virgin (use of Rome), excerpts
Pater Noster (in Greek)
msItem.incipit: f. 7r Πάτερ ἡμῶν ὁ ἐν τοῖς οὐρανοῖς
msItem.explicit: f. 7v ἀλλὰ ῥῦσαι ἡμᾶς ἀπὸ τοῦ πονηροῦ.

msItem.title: Ave Maria (in Greek)
msItem.explicit: f. 7v ὅτι σωτῆρα ἔτεκες τῶν ψυχῶν ἡμῶν.

msItem.title: Sanctus (in Greek)
msItem.incipit: f. 7v Ἅγιος ὁ θεὸς ἅγιος ἰσχυρός

msItem.title: Symbolum Constantinopolitanum I
msItem.explicit: f. 9v καὶ ζωὴν τοῦ μέλλοντος αἰῶνος. Ἀμήν
msItem.note: Ed. G.L. Dossetti, Il simbolo di Nicea e di Costantinopoli, Roma-Freiburg-Basel-Barcelona-Wien 1967, pp. 244-250

msItem.title: Excerpt from the Gospel of John (1, 1-14)
msItem.rubric: f. 9v Τὰ ἐφεξῆς τοῦ κατὰ Ἰωάννην ἁγίον εὐαγγελίου
msItem.incipit: f. 9v Ἐν ἀρχῇ ἦν ὁ λόγος

msItem.title: Excerpt from the Gospel of Luke (1, 26-38)
msItem.rubric: f. 11r Τὸ κατὰ Λουκᾶν ἅγιον εὐαγγέλιον
msItem.incipit: f. 11r Τῷ καιρῷ ἐκείνῳ ἀπεστάλη ὁ ἄγγελος Γαβριήλ
msItem.explicit: f. 13r γένοιτό μοι κατὰ τὸ ῥῆμά σου

msItem.title: Excerpt from the Gospel of Matthew (2, 1-12)
msItem.rubric: f. 13r Τὸ κατὰ Ματθαῖον ἅγιον εὐαγγέλιον
msItem.incipit: f. 13r Τῷ καιρῷ ἐκείνῳ τοῦ δὲ Ἰησοῦ γεννηθέντος ἐν Βεθλεέμ τῆς Ἰουδαίας
msItem.explicit: f. 15r δι’ ἄλλης ὁδοῦ ἀνεχώρησαν εἰς τὴν χώραν αὐτῶν.

msItem.title: Excerpt from the Gospel of Μark (16, 14-19)
msItem.rubric: f. 15r Τὸ κατὰ Μαρκὸν ἅγιον εὐαγγέλιον
msItem.incipit: f. 15r Τῷ καιρῷ ἐκείνῳ ἀνακειμένοις μαθῆταις τοῖς ἕνδεκα ἐφανερώθη
msItem.explicit: f. 16r διὰ τῶν ἐπακολουθούντων σημείων. Ἀμήν.

msItem.title: Gloria (in Greek)
msItem.incipit: f. 16v Δόξα ἐν ὑψίστοις θεῷ καὶ ἐπὶ γῆς εἰρἠνη

msItem.title: Blessing of the Table
msItem.incipit: f. 18r Εὐλογεῖτε. Ὁ θεὸς πᾶν τὸ παρατιθέμενον
msItem.explicit: f. 18v ὁ ζῶν καὶ βασιλεύων εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων. Ἀμήν.

msItem.title: Little office of the blessed Virgin
msItem.incipit: f. 19r Εἰς τὸν ὄρθρον. Κύριε τὰ χείλη μου ἀνοίξεις
msItem.explicit: f. 77v εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων. Ἀμήν.
msItem.finalRubric: f. 77v Τέλος τῆς ἀκολουθίας εἰτ' οὐν ὥρων τῆς μακαρίας, καὶ αἐιπαρθένου Μαρίας

msItem.title: Seven penitential Psalms (Ps. 6, 31, 37, 50, 101, 129, 142 [TLG 0527.027]) with litanies of the Saints and prayers, from the Greek translation of the Book of Hours
Septem psalmi paenitentiales cum litaniis sanctorum et orationibus, e translatione Graeca Horarum B. M. V. secundum conuetudinem Romanae Curiae
msItem.rubric: f. 77v Ἀρχὴ τῶν ἑπτὰ τῆς μετανοίας ψαλμῶν. Μὴ μνησθείης κύριε.
msItem.incipit: f. 78r Κύριε μὴ τῷ θυμῷ σοῦ ἐλέγξῃς με
msItem.explicit: f. 101v Αἱ τῶν πιστῶν ψυχαὶ διὰ τοῦ θείου ἐλέους ἀναπαυέσθωσαν ἐν εἰρήνῃ. Ἀπόκρισις. Ἀμήν.
msItem.finalRubric: f. 101v Τέλος τῶν ἑπτὰ τῆς μετανοίας ψαλμῶν

msItem.note: The text seems to have been copied from the Aldine edition (Venice 1497)

support.material:
ff. 1-106 Western paper, folded in octavo.
Watermarks:
Pitcher surmounted by a quatrefoil in the upper part of the leaf, on the edge, near the gutter, comparable (the watermark is never entirely visible) to Briquet Pot 12510-12511 , which are dated 1504 and 1509-1514 (France).

supportDesc.foliation: Modern pencil foliation, in Latin and Arabic numerals, in the upper margin, right: i + 1-107.

collation.p: The codex is formed by quaternions and ternions. Quire 1 is a quaternion which lost the 2nd and 3rd leaves (two stubs remain, without loss of text); quire 11 is a quaternion which lost the 8th leaf (without loss of text).

list.item: Quire 18-2 ff. 1-6( 2nd and 3rd leaf missing, no loss of text)

collation.signatures: Signatures in red ink, in Latin letters and numerals, in the lower margin of the recto of the first half of the quires (e.g. b, b ii, b iii, b iiii), from a (see a ii on f. 8r; the first leaf of the first quire has the number 1, see f. 7r) to n ( f. 98r).

supportDesc.condition: The codex is in good condition.

handNote.p: ff. 7r-101v Hand A: the texts were all written in a minuscule script, upright, regular in dimension.
The text is written in a brown ink; titles in red; initials in red and blue ink.
The scribe does not write iota subscript.

decoDesc.decoNote: On f. 7r there is a decorated border: a full frame surrounding the beginning of the text, composed of blue and gold acanthus leaves, green leaved stems with red flowers, and black sprays.

Illuminated initials:
f. 7r: initial in grey with a green leaved stem with two berries coloured in red and green, on a golden square with black sprays
f. 19r: initial in grey with a green leaved stem with two berries coloured in red and green, on a golden square with black sprays
f. 78r: initial in grey with a green leaved stem with two flowers coloured in blue, on a golden square with black sprays.
Decorated initials, coloured in red and blue, see e.g. ff. 33r, 48v, 53v.
Minor thick initials in red and blue ink throughout. Passim minor initials or simple letters in brown ink are covered in yellow wash.

additions.p: On the first, parchment, endleaf, f. [i] recto is written, in black ink, a note concerning the donation of the manuscript in 1930 (see Acquisition). The leaf bears writing, now faded, in Latin.

On the upper part of f. 1r there is a pen drawing of a ragged staff with twigs pruned away, concealing a note, possibly an ownership note (?). Below there are two Latin quotations from Ovid's Ars amatoria and Baptista Mantuanus' Contra poetas impudice loquentes. On the bottom right corner of the leaf there is an ink stamp with interlaced letters C C surmounted by a crown, maybe the initials of a previous owner.
On ff. 104v-105v is written in Latin, in a later hand, a theological debate, inc. Utrum dignitas amissa per mortale peccatum restituatur per penitentiale sacramentum.
On f. 106r is written the present shelfmark, MS. 325.
Old shelfmarks are written on f. 1v, H. VI. and 8 M.H , and on f. 6v N 609.

binding.p:
Early modern western binding (it is located in Flanders ca. 1520 in Wormald-Giles 1982, p. 315). Full leather cover, with reuse of previous leather, over millboards. Blind tooling on both boards: a geometrical pattern of a frame of four fillets, with a central rectangle filled with a border composed of stems with fruits and dragons; in the centre a vegetal motif with nuts. Gauffered edges.
140 90 ca. 25
binding.condition: Rebacked, parts of a previous leather covering have been used.

accMat.p: Two parchment leaves have been used as endleaves, ff. i, and 107. They show traces of Latin script, now mostly washed out.

origin.p: On the basis of the watermarks, and the style of the script and of the decoration, the manuscript can be dated probably between the end of the 15th c. and the first quarter of the 16th. Since the Greek translation of the Book of Hours was published by Aldus Manutius in 1497, the copy should be dated after this year. The manuscript was possibly produced in France (for this assumption see Wormald-Giles 1982, p. 315, and Easterling 1966, p. 190).

history.acquisition: It was given to the Museum by the Friends of the Fitzwilliam Museum in 1930 (see note in black ink on f. i recto, Given by the Friends of the Fitzwilliam Museum, 10 May 1930). A stamp of the Fitzwilliam Museum is present on f. 106r.

recordHist.source: Description (2021) draws partly on P. Easterling, Greek manuscripts in Cambridge: recent acquisitions by College Libraries, the Fitzwilliam Museum and private collectors, in: Transactions of the Cambridge Bibliographical Society 4.3, 1966, pp. 179-191: 190, and on F. Wormald, P.M. Giles, A descriptive catalogue of the additional illuminated manuscripts in the Fitzwilliam Museum acquired between 1895 and 1979 (excluding the McClean Collection), I, Cambridge, Cambridge University Press, 1982, p. 315

availability.p: Visitors to the Fitzwilliam Museum who wish to consult Collection material are required to apply to the Museum in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Fitzwilliam Museum: Study Room.

analytic.title: Greek manuscripts in Cambridge: recent acquisitions by college libraries, the Fitzwilliam Museum and private collectors.

monogr.title: Transactions of the Cambridge Bibliographical Society
A descriptive catalogue of the additional illuminated manuscripts in the Fitzwilliam Museum acquired between 1895 and 1979 (excluding the McClean Collection)
